title: Zombicide Black Plague Dashboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I you like me is a fan of Zombicide BP but find yourself with more than five friends that want to play so you always run out of dashboards and no more can be had untill June when the second wave of Kickstarter stuff is shipped you can always print your own.

Several more survivors are also avaliable at RPGgeek and other places.

This is not an exact copy of the original but is more to be considered a Q&D job.

What is missing and I welcome improvements is for instance numbers to the kill-o-meter and some kind of blue-yellow-orange-red markings.

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Notes:

No brim in use since the 188 mm width as about maximum my printer can make.
The holes need to be drilled with a 3 mm drill and then the Zombicide BP markers will fit.

All credit to my loving wife who used to design in Catia and learned Inventor to help me out with this. She has not yet mastered absolute sizes so you have to tweak this when slicing.
188 mm is a good width.

comments.text:
Would it be possible to do the XP numbers (0-43) indented along the bottom slider bar? I was thinking it would be cool to "wax" them like gamers used to have to with the old D&D dice.
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-hPRhp0qgRDs/U8M9rLsrGKI/AAAAAAAABek/rhjH_hXAwLw/s1600/newdice_10x6.jpg

author: anacastillejo

title: 120mm 12v PC fan Solder Fume Extractor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I bought a 240v soldering fume extractor and it came with some spare filters, since the cord on it was so short I can't even use it, I built a version to use a 120mm PC fan instead.

The filters it came with are 135 x 133 so that's what this thing holds (don't ask me why they're not perfectly square but one side is 2mm shorter).

Holes in it are 4.8mm which should accept an M5 screw.

It looks bent in the pictures because it is, I printed it in ABS and it warped like crazy, the actual model is flat on the front, I just wanted a quick test to check the center of gravity on those feet.

title: Ekobots - Magnetic levitator shield for arduino nano.

description.text:
Magnetic levitator shield for arduino nano.

This shield is for use with ojbect:

  • Ekobots - Levitator with arduino.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1392023

  • You can order the shield at:
    https://oshpark.com/shared_projects/kxH3Ak1b
    It was published in OSH Park by Thingiverse user krwynn:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/krwynn/about
    Thanks!

All you need:

  • 1x Arduino Board (Nano to use the shield);
  • 1x Electromagnet - ZYE1-P25/20 12V, 25mm diameter, 20mm height (ebay $7.00);
  • 1x Linear hall effect sensor - 49e (ebay Kit 5 - $1.50);
  • 1x Magnet cube 10mm (ufo_1) or magnet sphere 10mm (ufo_2);
  • 1x Darlington Transistor NPN - TIP120;
  • 1x Resistor 1K ohm;
  • 1x Diode N4007;
  • 1x Power supply 12V 1A (ebay $2.00);
  • 2x Micro switch;

Arduino firmware:

  • Levitator.ino - For normal people, with life and girl friend;
  • Levitator_PID.ino - If you do not have life and girl friend or
    if you have any kind of mental disorder, it was made for you... ;-).
  • I am testing a new firmware with safety mode, it turns off the
    electromagnet in case of fall of the permanent magnet.

Working mode:

  • The switch "+" increase the distance from the electromagnet.
  • The switch "-" decrease the distance from the electromagnet.

My videos:

  • Video 1 (3x block magnets 10mm x 10mm x 3mm + 8mm x 30mm threaded rod);
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w-jtu5cxl9o
  • Video 2 (1x cube magnet 10mm + Ufo 01 3D printed part);
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nXplyDKqs2s
  • Video 3 (1x sphere magnet 10mm + 8mm x 30mm threaded rod);
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AxjHF56DeiQ
  • Video 4 (1x cylinder magnet 20mm x 5mm):
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NttqFqB-nu4
  • Video 5 (2x cylinder magnets 20mm x 5mm):
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AIz9ystIPUo
  • Video 6 (2x ring magnets 19mm x 5mm):
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k7yBUj8GIgU
  • Video 7 (1x sphere magnet 10mm + Ufo 3D printed):
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VHKrIAETCA
  • Video 8 (Prototype version test):
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HpFQfXAwKzI

Attention:

  • See the images to mount the hall effect sensor;
  • The electromagnet alter the sensor real value for the permanent magnet;
  • Mount the hall effect sensor as far as possible from the electromagnet;
  • Use neodymium permanent magnets (it will not work with common magnets);
  • Use soft wires to make easy the assembly, small box, remember;

That's all folks!

description.text:
Framed within the project development MecaduinOpen printer, it arises as a tool for making the necessary elements for the development of future projects.
The MecaduinOpen system is based on printed pieces as link developing its entirety, so that we can have a printer is critical to the user to have at its disposal the possibility to build their own projects.
It takes as its starting point the printer design to be developed must be very economical, with simple and easy to print parts and requires no assembly instructions, tools or complicated processes.
The result is a compact, robust and easy and logical assembly machine.
Printing time of parts is below 20 h, the parts are simple in design and therefore easy to print.

title: USB thumbdrive holder for M8 rod

description.text:
Edit: V2 added, which uses less material
Updated V2: The script was wrong, H and B were swapped! Oh my. Remix of the classic endstop holder to hold a USB thumbdrive. Useful if you store firmware, calibration data and replacement parts on a USB stick and keep forgetting where it is. It can also be used to hold the plug of the printer's cable when you're not using it. The design is parametric, so you can change the size of the hole if you need to; for example to hold tools.
Print and fix to your printer with an M3 nut and screw. Insert USB device.

title: Hanoi Tiger Vietnam Wall Hanger (Bas Relief 3D Scan)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I found a nice 3D scan of a Vietnamese bas-relief of a tiger. 123D Catch scans aren't 3D printable because they are surfaces, no solids - so I put in some work to make this printable.

I made the surface solid by adding a frame around it and merging that with the tiger relief, the frame has a ridged hole in the back so it can hang on a wall.

The original scan by ''diedevanvree'' can be found here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Hanoi-tiger-Vietnam/4951899

http://www.3dwp.nl

title: Heatbed strain relief for Duplicator i3

description.text:
Wanhao Duplicator i3 v1.0 - Use Heatbed_Strain_Relief_1-6.STL
Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.0 & v2.1 - Use Heatbed_Strain_Relief_V2_1-2.STL

The movement of the wires soldered to the heatbed was quite large and over time they might degrade and break off.

This strain relief should reduce the movement a lot at the solder joints, prolonging the life of the wires to the headbed.

Print in PET-G or ABS;
DO NOT USE PLA, IT WILL NOT HANDLE THE TEMPERATURE!

Depending on your printer settings, you might have to clean up the gap with a file.

Additional items you'll need:
1 pcs M3 screw (Min length 10mm, Max length 18mm)
1 pcs M3 lock nut
1 pcs zip tie

IMPORTANT:
Since various filaments have different temperatures when they start to deform (not just between ABS and PET-G, but with different fillers, additives and colors), it is VERY important to check to make sure the strain relief does not deform over time.
If it does, remove it, then you are better off without this item until you have a filament that works with the temperatures of the heatbed.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

comments.text: This design didn't work for my Maker Select V2.   The cables come off the plate more or less perpendicular to the plate right at the hole.  Also the piece wouldn't slip onto the plate far enough to let me attach it with a screw.  (the buildtac is removed)  I'm not complaining. just mentioning that it didn't work for the printers that were assembled the day mine was. :)  Next time I have the chance I'll measure the placement of the hole and the bed thickness etc.
comments.author: jeffbearer

comments.text: I do apologize for the late reply. Have now added a version for V2.0 and V2.1 printers that hopefully should fit now.
comments.author: jeffbearer

comments.text: How does this attach to the bed?  It looks like you need to drill a hole for the screw to go through...
comments.author: sventhepaddler

comments.text:
There should already be a hole there. New printers may have the build-tac thing surface sticker covering the hole so check from underneath. If you can see a hole in the heatbed from underneath then you can just use a knife and poke a hole in the build surface there.
On some printers there is a warning sticker also covering this hole.
comments.author: sventhepaddler

comments.text: Found it under the warning sticker.  Thanks!

comments.text: Works great. Good work!
comments.author: stefanli

comments.text:
Thank you very much for making this.
I was just wondering this morning if strain on those wires and solder joints might end up being a problem.
PETG print and install coming right up.
comments.author: roefoo

comments.text:
Dont forget to post a make of the part if it works well for you :)
I have yet to hear of someone having the wires fail, but mine after half a year do look worn. Seems like it's just a matter of time until they will fail and if they do, it can be quite catastrophic due to the high amount of current going to the heatbed.

When the "Shack" didn't have single AA battery holders in stock for my 4-H project, I whipped this up.
It's a single AA holder with a receptacle for a small bulb. The channel along the side holds the connecting wire and by feeding the wires through the holes, acts as a strain-relief.
Use it to see what can conduct electricity!

Strip some solid copper wire - e.g. a solid conductor from a Cat-5 cable. Feed it through the end-holes a few times to make the battery contact. Do the same for the other side.
Pop a 1.5v bulb in the receptacle (RS 272-1139). Twist one end of the bulb's wire around one of the battery contacts.
Feed stranded wire up and through a few of the holes in the side channel for strain relief. Connect one wire to the other battery contact. Connect the second wire to other end of the bulb.
Optionally add alligator clips to the end of the probe wires.

title: Circular fan-duct for blower for my custom carriage

description.text:
Circular fan-duct for blower for this carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1275203. Made for the common 50x50x15 blower by Sunon. The blower is simply fixated by a snap-in fitting. No screws are required.

The benefit of a circular fan is a confined, symmetrical and downward facing air-flow. No dead zones are created. See also this awesome investigation by Desi Quintans http://www.desiquintans.com/coolingtests2. In contrast to the surround duct investigated by Desi the duct presented here has a tightly focused airflow, thus probably being a combination of a sharp nozzle and surround type. Nevertheless check the attached experimentally visualized airflow by means of smoke demonstrating the focused, confined long range airflow.

Why using a blower/radial fan? A radial fan has a lower airflow but has a higher pressure as compared to an axial fan which makes it the right choice for high-flow-resistance ducts like this one.

[Update]

  • Added a version (v2) with additional mounting option to pull up the duct on the back side by a rubber band or a string.
  • Added a version (v3) which also cools the throat of the hotend. The bottom exit holes are made larger to compensate for the loss of pressure in the duct.
  • Added a throat nozzle to reduce throat cooling.

Supports:

No

Notes:

Printing of the circular openings is not easy. I suggest printing quite cold to have good bridges. I print with PLA at 175°C.

Please select proper printing orientation.
You might want to clean the small circular openings with a tiny metal screwdriver.

I decided to keep the output openings close to the nozzle to cool only the freshly deposited filament. I did not want to cool the heated bed. Furthermore, I did not want to cool the nozzle by the airflow to allow for variable cooling.

description.text:
Needed a pen holder on my desk and wanted it to be unnecessarily over the top to prove a point. I took the 3D scan of the Statue of David by fabskill (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281053). Gave it a base, hollowed it out and cut the top off at an angle so that the print would stay balanced even if it was full of objects.

I've added supports which aren't 100% necessary and might easily break during the print. They do help though, especially with the bottom of the print. I find it looks even better if you treat it with acetone afterwards.

I also anchored it to the desk with blu-tac. This is not necessary but it is quite light so it stops it moving. Print at 100% infill or another high value as it has already been hollowed out. Don't enable vase mode as the bottom will mess up. The supports should just snap off, the internal support is partially removable.

I printed in white to match the desk.

title: CTC Printer - Spring based anti-vibration feet

description.text:
Should also work on the replicator, makerbot etc.

Needed to drastically quieten my CTC Dual Replicator 3D printer. I had used systems in the past that silenced the printer via foam or a 3D print itself acting as a spring. I saw Simonwlchan's shock absorbers for his printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:916254) and decided to make one compatible with the CTC printer. I took Superwoodle's design for CTC feet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:958125) and recreated Simonwlchan's design to work with the CTC feet.

The spring holders are designed for the large packs of springs from eBay marked as 'Extruder Springs for Ultimaker/Makerbot'. The ebay page I bought them from described the measurements as the following: Wire diameter: 1.2mm, Inner diameter: 5mm, Outside diameter 7.5mm, Height 20mm.

I'm unsure what size the nuts/bolts are, as they are unmarked. But are roughly M4/M5. It screws through rather than into, so the size of the bolts isn't too important. As long as they are not too long or too wide.

I also realise now that the part that attaches to the printer and the lid of the base could of been 1 single object eliminating the need for nuts and bolts. It's pointless me making this change now though as I have already printed these and they work flawlessly.

It can be quite tricky to actually attach to the 3D printer as there's nothing holding the feet together, you have to hold it together while you install them. You'll need 4 bases, 4 lids and 4 feet attachments printed. The single design works on all 4 corners

Once installed, 99% of the vibration noise is gone, all the vibrations are kept within the printer itself. I find most of the noise/vibration being passed down now is more the weight of the printer constantly shifting. They also raise the printer enough to make the makerboard fan have enough air clearance (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1297824).

Printer:

CTC Replicator Dual

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% infill

Notes:

Rafts not necessary, I only use them to make it easier to remove from the heated bed.

comments.text: Works beyond awesomely in minimizing noise and vibration! I paired all 4 sets up with the springs specified in the original posting and for good measure added (Isolate It: Sorbothane Vibration Isolation Circular Pad) 2.25" rounds above and below the feet. This has literally allowed me from being banned by the wife and children from printing at night to being able to print 24/7, and has taken almost all the vibration marks I was seeing in my prints out of the equation without having to slow my speeds. Thanks for sharing with the world!

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:834725

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=834725

Using the following options:

Text = Karinny
twist = -0.5
Loop_x_position = 11
Loop_font = Chewy
height = [5,6,4,5,4,3,5,4,6]
center = 60
Loop_character = o
spacing = [10,12,12,11,10.5,11.2,11.5,11.3,15]
Loop_y_position = 0
Font_name = Chewy
Rotation = 45

Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/DanielNoree After watching the infamous video from a few years back where Z-Corp prints a fully working wrench i decided i wanted to do the same thing on my own printer. Now, i am not talking about a "print-several-pieces-and-then-assemble" version which there are already a ton of on the internet.
What i wanted to do was something i could print and that would actually be fully working straight out of the printer.
I like to think i came pretty close. All you need to do is to remove the internal support and your done! Keep in mind this is a proof of concept, i just wanted to see if i could do it. Updated 2013-10-16: Added "Printable Wrench W Longer Screw" which has a longer "screw" (3mm). Updated 2013-08-30: I have added two new files. One with a slightly bigger gap between moving parts. This one has 0,55mm gap instead of 0,35mm. Let me know if it works out (in particular with PLA). I have also added a STEP file with no support for anyone who maight want it. Here is a short video: https://youtu.be/Eq_JI3yctJ8 Experimantal "heavy duty" version: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printable-wrench-reworked Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/DanielNoree
Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instagram - Vimeo - LinkedIn

• Print

comments.text: Solved! Easy fix for stuck screw! After hours and trying thing on this thread like freezing etc, I finally found a 30 sec trick that worked like a charm.  I used my dremel tool tiniest drill and put a hole through it straight down. then I used that same bit to twist it free and heard it break free. now it turns easily.  I actually used another bit same size diameter just so as not to break the drill bit one.  This is way better solution than mangling the screw with pliers and screwdriver which I also tried. I hope this idea helps someone else having troubles! Thanks for the great design, it's very cool!

comments.text: I think I know why the author can print one with his Makerbot while Repraps cannot. Correct me if I'm wrong (because I don't have a Reprap), the Makerbot's ReplicatorG software can allow you to do "partial support" while the Reprap's breakaway support material is all or nothing. With "partial support", the Makerbot will make a minimum of supports so that you won't be printing a lot of supports in between the gears. Therefore, you can break free and spin the gears after printing. However, Reprap operators with all or nothing supports will print too much support material so that the gears can't break free. comments.text: I finally got this printing well in ABS after dealing with a lot of feed problems with the stock mechanism on a Replicator 2X.  I printed the version with the large gaps at the default size and things snapped apart and started working very easily. Very impressive! I am printing with 25% fill and 0.2 mm thickness. I also added some Makerware helper disks under the little pylons that support the break away bits.  Before I did that, they peeled up and broke loose before the fourth layer was complete.  I switched to a different filament (that claimed to be metallic silver but, of course, it's just grey) and noticed that it was significantly harder to remove the plugs and get the screw working. I finally figured out why.  They awesome-wrench-filament was 1.7 mm in diameter and the it's-really-stuck-together wrench was printed with 1.8 mm filament.  It turns out I was supposed to measure the filament thickness and change the filament diameter parameter in the profile!  Who knew?  The feed mechanism/software pushed the same number of centimeters of filament through the nozzle for each print, but the difficult wrench had almost 6% more filament squirted into it - hence the fused gaps. Thanks for the cool part! It's trying to get these cool ones to work that drags everyone through the pain of actually learning how to control these machines properly.

And I've noticed in the three that I haven't broken, that the adjustable part of the wrench usually needs a bit of light finger pressure for guidance to keep it from binding up.   There seems to be a bit of slop in it.  Perhaps it's the gaps, but could it also be possible that, if the threaded cylinder that moves up and down within the wrench, were made a little longer, that it would  help to keep the adjustable piece better aligned?  There seems to be a 1/4" of room at the top where it could be lengthened.  This is an awesome design, and if it could be perfected it would be truly amazing.   It is so close now!  I wish that I had the skills to do more than offer suggestions.  Perhaps I will get there someday.

comments.text:
Printed on a Makergear M2 with Simplify3D Creator software on 1.75mm blue ABS from SainSmart. 105C bed, 220C extruder.
No bed tape. Raft was 2 layer, 5mm offset, and 50% infill on the raft to hold the pieces
very steady. Rest of the infill was at 25%. Skirt was 2 layer, 0mm
offset with 2 outlines. Print quality set to High (0.15mm layer height),
top and bottom 3 layers as solid, 2 shells. Bed fan off. No printing issues, but the wrench was locked up tight.

When slicing this with SF50 I'm getting tons of the following errors:
This should never happen, there is a hole in the triangle mesh, each edge should have two faces.
3999 [2657] [1343, 1345]
Something will still be printed, but there is no guarantee that it will be the correct shape.
Once the gcode is saved, you should check over the layer with a z of:
5.7

title: Blank Replicator 1 / CTC / Flashforge / Wanhao / QIDI Backplate Set

description.text:
This is a set of various backplates for the Replicator 1 and clones.

Apparently, not all clone machines have the same width, some are Standard 124.30 and others are 128.30. I have added additional models to compensate for this.

The cutout plates are not designed for Replicator 2 / Clones, they are for Replicator 1 / Clones but have the same Replicator 2 style cutout.

As requested by comments, I've added:

Standard 124.30mm wide:
5.5mm backplate, 8mm backplate, 10mm backplate
5.5mm backplate /w cutout, 8mm backplate /w cutout, 10mm backplate /w cutout

Oversized 128.30mm wide:
5.5mm backplate, 8mm backplate, 10mm backplate
5.5mm backplate /w cutout, 8mm backplate /w cutout, 10mm backplate /w cutout

Oversized 128.30mm wide, support added:
5.5mm backplate
5.5mm backplate /w cutout

Will work with Truck V1 and Truck V2
Simple gearbox with helical gears for 540 brushed motors.
Print and add some grease, works great!
The hardware you need:
4mm axles
4mm bearings, I used 624zz bearings.
M3 grubscrews for locking the gears

You can see more videos of the V1 and V2 truck over at my youtube channel:
http://www.youtube.com/c/MrCrankyfaceProjects

Edit 2016-03-12: Added bighelical32t_0.7m_PIN.stl, this is the output gear with a 1.5mm hole for putting a pin through the gearshaft, this seems to work better than just using grub screws but requires drilling through the metal shaft.

Edit 2016-03-27: Updated with new gearbox housing that'll work in both Truck V1 and Truck V2.
Edit 2016-04-23: Apparently the new gearbox housing had some tight tolerances around the gear so I made some more space there, only file changed is mount2.stl
Also added spacer.stl which helps align the gears, put it behind the big middle gear.

Check me out at:
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/MrCrankyfaceProjects
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/mr.crankyface/
3d hubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/malm%C3%B6/hubs/mrcrankyface
Patreon: http://patreon.com/Mrcrankyface

Printer:

Custom CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The pieces should print fine without support or raft if you rotate them correctly.
All my prints are in Colorfabb XT but PLA should work fine depending on how high your motor revs.
High revs and unperfect gears can cause gearbox damage from the friction caused temperature.

My brother (also a Lutheran pastor) is building a Luther themed basement bar, and he needed some cool beer tap handles to match his decor, so I created this one and a few others, and more are in the works. This one is pretty general, just the Luther seal with the 3 watch words of the reformation below it making the base. The 3 watch words Sola Scriptura - By Scripture alone (as opposed to tradition) Sola Fide - By Faith Alone (as opposed to deeds) and Sola Gratia - By Grace Alone (as opposed to your own merit). And Luther's seal itself is a summation of Luther's theology, so there are at least 8 - 10 sermons all in this one tap handle. That'll make you think twice before visiting my brother's bar and sampling all of his home-brews.

Thanks to the person who put Luther's seal on thingiverse, this would never have happened without that. I added standard tap threading to be base, it works for my brother's tap.

Thanks to the wife for the help with meticulous painting.

I made a timelapse of its printing check it out, "now with exciting (public domain) music" https://youtu.be/DIJ1frwUrEo

description.text:
Behold... the BatCar!
This is a project for a race in the Carlos III University. Our car uses a spring as acceleration. Our system may be a little bit complicated but we think it works propperly.
Also, it has took us a long time to print all the pieces and make the box, so we'll start correcting the mistakes by now.
ADVISEMENT: THE FILES HAVE SOME ERRORS, AND THERE ARE THINGS WHICH NEED TO BE FIXED, SO I RECOMMEND YOU NOT TO PRINT THIS YET.

You will need:
1x Batcar
8x Wheel_EXT
4x Wheel_INT
1x Platform
1x Screw (anyone which fits in the Platform hole)
1x Holder (Still not fixed)
1x Spring Axis
1x Spring*
1x Box (made manually)** *: You must use one very similar to ours until we parametrize the whole project :(
This are the spring measures:
Longitude (Expanded) - 74 mm
Diameter - 16 mm
Longitude (Contracted) - 20 mm
Diameter of the thread - 1 mm
Distance between each turn - 6~7 mm **: You will have to make the box manually. We first tried to made it with the printer, but it took more than 3 hours and it is so big that it tore apart because the plastic cooled before the next layer was extruded, so it will peel off.
The box measures are:
Inside width - 109 mm
Inside longitude - 104 mm
Distance between the bottom of the holder hole and the box floor - 27 mm
Width of the holder hole - 8 mm
Inside Longitude of the holder hole - 95 mm
Inside Longitude of the car-stopping wall - 45 mm
I give you the inside measures because the width of the walls doesn't matter, use the material you like most =)
You may not want to use a lateral left wall as I did (see last image), or if you do, make it shorter than I did because if it hasn't the properly measures, the car will be stopped by it and never be released. The wheels are designed as a bearing, but without balls. You need to print 2 Wheel_EXT Pieces and 1 Wheel_EXT in order to make 1 single wheel. The spring axis need to be glued to the platform. It is made to not let the car turn or spin when it goes out of the box. OF COURSE, to make it a BatCar, you will need a Batman Symbol. You may use this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12381 HOW TO SET ALL THE PIECES TOGETHER:
-The wheels must be glued (Wheel_EXT with Wheel_EXT, taking care not to stick Wheel_INT with them), but they don't need to be glued to the car, as they can be attached only with some pression.
-The platform is joined to the holder by a screw (we need to remake the holder, as this mechanism was thought afterwards).
-The spring axis must be glued to the platform, so it fits with the BatCar hole. We have to create a piece that holds the spring when the car is released. HOW ALL THIS CRAP WORKS (xD):
Having all the pieces joined, we press the car against the spring, introducing the spring axis and the spring into the car hole. Then, we move it so it get stucked in the box (see last image).
To release, we move the holder in the back of the box to the right, so when the car don't have a wall to hold it, it will be released and the spring will transmit some acceleration to the BatCar :)
As the front of the car is rectangular and it has an axis inside, it won't turn when it is almost in the edge.

title: Challenging Complex Volume-Cells Designs by Dizingof

description.text:
Since i stumbled upon the 3D printing scene in 2009, i've always was and still am fascinated with design process R&D.

Amongst dozens of my design processes i've picked these 3 and applied them on simple Math shapes - icosahedron & dodecahedron.

These design processes have unique properties aside from aesthetics / decor - and can be applied into any shape even irregular as you can see in this YouTube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lTqavWB9FK4
and this 3d viewer:
https://sketchfab.com/models/53e9613d02664e719c0cca3170a4136e

They are, theoretically, as strong as solid shapes but with less material used and can be applied on various decor, architectural, landscapes constructions.

I've designed and uploaded these 3 samples inspired by the new revolutionary Metal jetting 3D printer - http://www.xjet3d.com

Dizingof

comments.text: Should I use supports for these?
comments.author: BooMeringue

comments.text: I mainly intended for these designs to be tested on high resolution 3d printers - specifically Metal.

This is a funny and basic train toy. I make it for a car race of my University (Carlos III, Madrid). -> Rendered image and files ChucuchÃº V1 .scad and .stl, are only for a global vision, THEY ARE NOT PRINTABLE < - Here you can see how it works: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTDau6R_qxk ((Photos and video are from old version; I still haven't had enough time to print the one new.)) Enjoy it!! ^^

Train:
  • First of all, you have to print the four parts.
  • Then, fix them with a hot glue gun or some other strong glue.
    • Axes and mechanism:

  • Print 4 castor wheels (from Obijuan->thing:7989) with these characteristics:

    oring_diameter=20 (Internal diameter);
    oring_thickness=3;
    drill=4; (It depends on the thickness of your metallic threaded rod).
    wheel_width=6; (Here you can use what width you want).

  • To make these wheels, you need 4 o-rings (diameter: 20 mm).
  • For each axis you need also a metallic threaded rod 4x75mm (diameter, lenght).
  • Print an elastic-band-holder.
  • An elastic band.

  • Some hex nuts.

  • Join all this as you can see on the photo (or improve the configuration :P).
  • To hold the elasctic band, you can make a hole on part 3, or you can use an eye lag.

description.text:
I made a couple of bases to mount my phone to my treadmill. I printed two of the legs and bolted them to the treadmill, then I just slip whichever base I need onto the legs. My phone is a Samsung Galaxy S4 (yes, I need to update) and my son's phone is an LG G4. You could screw the legs to just about anything you wanted and have a great phone mount.

If you say to yourself "Wow, I wish I had one of those but that won't fit my phone" then let me know what model you have and if I get a minute I'll try to modify the file to work for your phone.

Hope you enjoy them, thanks.

This is and end mill laser cut holder for the 10 piece grizzly end mill set seen here: http://www.grizzly.com/products/g9757 I use 3/4" x 3/4" x 1/16" aluminum for the supports or columns. This is a method that I invented. I call this self threading square tube insert method. The 4 holes on the masonite (hard board) are exactly positioned so that when they are all screwed in they "self thread" into the aluminum corners. The use of longer bolts will give a stronger hold. However for this project I used 2x 1" bolts and 2x 1/4" socket head screws. The masonite used is 1/8". The top layer consists of 2 sheets identically cut (minus the engraving on the 2nd one). The first bottom layer is exactly the same as the top (minus the engraving). This allows for the end mills to "slide" into place and not move around. The last layer is the file that has the work "bottom" in it. It basically is only the outline and no end mill holes.

Screws:
The online site I use does not allow for direct linking so here it is:
http://www.boltdepot.com/product.aspx?cc=13&cs=71&cm=25&cd=1220
you need at least: 8x of #7981 (1/4")
8x of #5009 (1") Aluminum Tube:
Get your 3/4 Aluminum Tube cut into 4x 1.2" parts. I use a metal cutting horizontal band saw. However a plain hack saw would work too. I also brush the metal with a belt sander. It adds a cool look. Masonite Board:
Get your 1/8" material and cut 1 top layer with engraving. Cut the next 2 layers the exact same as the top but no engraving. Lastly cut the bottom layer. Assembly:
Get the two top board parts and insert the 2x 1" screws and 2x 1/4" screws so that they are sticking out about 1/8". I like to place the 2x 1" screws in opposite corners then the 1/4" in the remaining corners. Rinse repreat for the rest of the top. Place the aluminum tubes under the top board so that all screws slip into the insides of all the tubes. Once aligned do 1 screw at a time on the same column until all columns are screwed in. Finally do the same for the bottom. Done! My Blog to read more about it here:
http://www.synthetos.com/blog/laser-cut-end-mill-holder/

title: Gondola for v-plotter/polargraph
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my take on the Gondola for a v-plotter/polargraph machine

Its meant to be light weight, use as little filament as possible, have the pen at the centre of the pivot point, not require much in the way of additional hardware (no big bearings needed), be quick and easy to assemble/disassemble and have a push fit pen holder so I can do quick pen changes.

Pen holder/organizer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393182
Pen depth setting tool: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393200

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Huxley

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The double arm, weight arm and pen holder will require printing with support.

For the arms, once printed, it is important that they are clean and free of any support material as they will need to slide around the gondola and past each other so this could be a tricky print, or require lots of finishing. I spun my Gondola in a drill for a while to free up the rotation of the arms. Some silicone grease on the pivot point will also help.

Assembly

Should be straight forward, but as mentioned in print settings, finishing the pivot parts well is essential, see the assembly pictures.

Align the 3 arms pivot points, with the 'single arm' inside the 'double arm' and both inside the 'weight arm', slide the whole thing onto the Gondola and push fit the 'swing arm collar' to keep them in place.

The two arms that attach to the ball chain are designed with slots to accept the chain. There is a slight recess on one side of the ball chain 'sockets'. These should both face the same way. When you fit your ball chain, you should pass the chain through from the other side so a single ball can sit in the recess.Drop the chain thru the larger of the two holes at the end of the arm and push the chain up to the end of the arm and it should stay locked in place. Alternatively, if you are using string, you can tie on to the holes in the end of the arms.

The pen holder (pen collar) takes an M3 screw to secure the pen. The hole should be about the right size to allow an M3 screw to self tap, but your mileage may vary. Use a drill and/or a tap if you need to. The pen collar should be a push fit with the Gondola, if it isn't you might have to tweak your printer settings (or the scad files).

The weight arm is designed to take an M4 screw with a large washer at the bottom, packed with nuts (they fit snugly inside the bearings inner race) and a number of 608 'skate' bearings (they are cheap and I had a bunch sitting round doing nothing). You could just tie a suitable weight to the bottom of this arm.
Designed in OpenSCAD. Some of these parts are parametric, some aren't and some are a mix.

title: Raspberry Pi Enclosure with extra hole for momentary power (P6 header) push button

description.text:
This laser cut Raspberry Pi enclosure design features light pipes for the status LEDs and obscures the T-slots for a nice clean looking enclosure. All off board connectors are accessable with the top off and you can use standard ribbon cable connectors through the case to hook up the expansion header as well. Spacing of the top layers have been adjusted so these should be compatible with pi plates when they become availiable with minimal additional hardware. UPDATE:
The design has been updated to support both the models of the Raspberry Pi board (A & B) and include better standoffs. Updates thanks to Thingiverse user RoboLemur for the design updates. UPDATE:
The design has been updated to add a new hole for a push button to be connected to the P6 header. https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11992

title: PrintRite DIY 3d Printer Spool Holder Supports

description.text:
Here we have a set of three spool holder supports designed to be used with the Print-Rite DIY 3d printer when used in conjunction with the Print-Rite stand by Fab-ster (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1216052). It has been designed to fit stand material with a width of 18mm.

You may have to adjust the dimensions to fit your stand but I have included the STL files as well as the gcode. The two outside supports have been designed to fit the slots on the Print-Rite spool holder to stop any movement with the centre flat for support only.

Mounting
Drill a small 2mm hole on the lower rear bracket back support and secure to the stand upright with a small screw or I guess you could hot glue it.

If you have not made this stand (or something similar) give it a go as it makes a huge difference to the print quality.

title: Parametric(ish) Ball Chain Pulley for v-plotter/polargraph machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parametric(ish) OpenSCAD ball chain pulley wheels for a v-plotter/polargraph machine.

I've included a few stls. 2 different size pulleys for 4 & 5mm shaft steppers.

Hopefully the scad is easy to understand. As mentioned in the scad file, the pully size you ask the script for, might not be the size you get because the script works out the nearest size pulley that can accomodate x number of evenly spaced balls. The script will tell you in the scad console what the final circumference is. You can then use that value in your software.

The script ball chain settings are for the metal chain commonly available from hardware chains in the UK (see http://bit.ly/20xqx43) but can be configured to suit whatever chain you get (I hope).

description.text:
Need a secure Uno/Ethernet Shield plate and box combo that will keep assets safe during a fall and allow for under and over plate wire runs to your pins?  
If so, print this puppy!

I ended up with a thick post base plate and box setup with an integrated Uno locking clip. I created the attached stl files from the also attached SketchUp file so you can feel free to mod. Also, if you haven't tried Google SketchUp for 3D modeling it is pretty nice (and free) you just need to add an stl export plugin ( (skp_to_dxf.rb) http://www.guitar-list.com/download-software/convert-sketchup-skp-files-dxf-or-stl ) and then export in mm for Gcode creation. All units pictured were printed via:
MK6+
1.75mm filament
.4 nozzle
ABP with aluminum plate topper and titanium belt covered in kapton Print the plate for sure, then decide if you need one of the tops depending on your setup. Arduino on!

title: Samyang 10mm F2.8 ED AS NCS CS Tripod Bracket

description.text:
Now I belong too to the proud user group of this nice WA lens :)
After making first tests and pictures, I found a little disadvantage combined with a relative small camera like my PEN EP 5:

A tripod mount like other heavy lenses are supported with was missing here.

Sure, a WA lens is not supposed to get fixed on a tripod in common use, but for night shots or more-step panoramic pictures a tripod is needed. At least have to develop a nodal point sledge further ; )

The lens isn’t with 620 gr not really light. So I thought it would be a good idea for tripod use, to carry the camera with the lens and put not the whole load on the cameras lens bayonet.
The MFT version is supplied with a extending-tube that is needed to bridge the distance of the short DSLR version. This tube has space enough to get used for a bracket around.

But now let it print or print it by your self if you like it..

Additional stuff:

2x Hex-socket screws M3x40 plus 2 nuts M3
1 Tripod-adaptor 1/4" UNC - 3/8" UNC.
Keep an eye on them and look that they have some more than one thread turn and a stable neck. There is much cheap bs sold in the web and not worth to carry expensive equipment.

Tools:

3mm drill bit
3/8" - 16 UNC taper
(People living in metric-country like me, can order this "uncommon" taper for less bucks in the www)

Final assembly:

Drill the screw holes out so the screws can turned easy in their place.
Cut the thread in the tripod-screw hole. Take care that the taper is adjusted in right angle while drilling. The hole is still designed for the fitting core diameter. Now screw the adaptor tight in.
Mount the two parts on the lens and tight the screws to the point the bracket is fixed without turning around. Keep a small gap to the aperture ring while fixing. Otherwise it will block the ring.
Now you can fix the tripod plate and get happy with it..

title: Modular Replicator 2 Top Mount Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
Of all the filament holders out there, I thought the top mounts were the best. During my initial Replicator 2 upgrade phase I used brackett27's design but I soon saw room for improvement. My main contributions to this type of mount are:
-one part for all 4 sides (instead of left and right, etc)
-modular add in capability (for rods and magnets to hold spools and tools)
-centralizing tube for spools
-improved aesthetics
-less tangling or jamming from too much or too little resistance on spool
-no supports required (follows 45 degree rule) Note:
I would suggest a few helper disks via makerware
Should be no need for rafts McMaster-Carr Hardware:
  • M6 x 16 mm flange-head socket cap screws to hold the supports in (#92235A238)
  • 3x 3/8 x 2' threaded rod - one to hold the spools and two to guide the filament. The threads keep the filament from moving too far to the left and right and wrapping around another spool (#98804A031)
  • 3/8 hex nuts (any will do) - to hold the rod in place. I got wing nuts for easier hand tightening
  • Round tube - 2" OD, 1-7/8" ID - to hold the Makerbot spool centralized around the threaded rod and allow it to spin and dispense filament (#8585K64)
    • Misc Item:
    1/4" x 1/4" Neodymium Magnet cylinder - these fit into the holes on all sides to hold up tools or decorations. Easily removed and moved around. Update (2013-9-8)
    I've added a snap on filament guide that attached to the threaded rods. This makes things less noisy during printing and keeps the filament in line. Make sure to attach them as shown in the pictures though or else your filament will hang up on them. When installed correctly it should slide smoothly out. Areas I'm still working on:
  • I left the top open to expansion. I might just print caps that snap in with magnets to make it look more finished
  • The groove on the bottom that prevents the top screws from hitting the supports is a little too big

Print at least 2 supports
Take out existing corner screws
Attach supports with new longer screws
Assemble the spool rod with the threaded rod in the middle, then a tube end, then the tube, then another tube end
Slide filament spools onto the spool rod
Set the assembled spool rod on top of the supports
Thread optional filament guide rods through the supports right underneath the spools Print
Profit

author: scool

title: Pen depth setting tool for v-plotter/polargraph machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pen depth setting tool for my Gondola and pen holder (pen collar).

The idea is that you set one pen to the correct depth and use that to set the depth on this tool. Lock the tool with the locking screw and you can then quickly and easily set the correct depth of the other pens.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393028 for pen holder (pen collar) and push fit Gondola.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393182 for a pen holder to hold multiple pens in their individual pen holders (pen collars) - I think I need to rename the push fit pen holder as pen collar...

Anyway, this is a work in progress as this was supposed to be part of the multi-pen holder but I haven't finished it and my printer is making a mess of it so sizes might need tweaking. I'm including it as part of the release of all the files I've been working on for a while now.

author: Shreddieeddie

title: 3D Printer Fan Hub Controller for CTC / Flashforge / Replicator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I built an internal and manual fan controller for up to 5 standard 12V PC-Fans. It should fit many different printers, but I designed it for my Replicator-Clone.

The Fan controller I used was the Aerocool F5XT:
http://www.aerocool.com.tw/en/fan-controller/single-bay/f5xt

The circuit board can be loosened very easy and the buttons / sliders are only clipped in place.

First I printed the "Mount Pattern" and drilled the mounting holes and the slots for the sliders (using a 3mm drill).
Then I printed the spacers, buttons and covers and all fits together with only 2 M3 Screws (or other if you use a bigger drill).
Note: The cover does not have any holes, you have to glue it in place or (like me) drill the holes by hand. I did this, becaus a miss-aligned the mount pattern a little bit and could fix it in this way.

UPDATE 03/12/2016

I added the Slider Button V2 (tighter tolerances). I also Uploaded the .stp for the slider button so you can adjust the design, if you find they wont fit properly.
